content.text: The *zero conditional* is used to describe situations that are always true when a certain condition is met. It deals with facts, laws of nature, and established truths‚Äînot possibilities or hypotheticals.

items: Used for general truths
Used for scientific facts
Describes routines or rules

content.text: The zero conditional is common in instructions, rules, and scientific writing.
The zero conditional uses the *present simple tense* in both the condition ('if' clause) and the result (main clause).

items: If water reaches 100¬∞C, it boils.
If you mix red and blue, you get purple.
If people eat too much, they gain weight.

content.text: You can reverse the order: *'It boils if water reaches 100¬∞C.'*

rules.rule_title: When to Use the Zero Conditional

content.text: Use the zero conditional when the result of the condition is *always true*. It states predictable outcomes rather than possibilities.

items: Scientific facts: 'If you heat ice, it melts.'
General truths: 'If you don‚Äôt water plants, they die.'
Rules and instructions: 'If the light is red, you stop.'
Habits: 'If she works late, she feels tired the next day.'

content.text: Many learners confuse the zero conditional with other forms or use incorrect verb tenses.

items: ‚ùå If it rains, I will get wet. ‚úÖ If it rains, I get wet. *(Zero vs. First conditional)*
‚ùå If water reached 100¬∞C, it boils. ‚úÖ If water reaches 100¬∞C, it boils. *(Incorrect tense)*
‚ùå If he eat too much, he feels sick. ‚úÖ If he eats too much, he feels sick. *(Subject‚Äìverb agreement)*

content.text: Never use 'will' in the result clause of the zero conditional.
The zero conditional is just one of several conditional structures in English. The key difference is that it refers to *real and always true* situations.

items: Zero Conditional: Real facts ‚Äî 'If you freeze water, it turns to ice.'
First Conditional: Possible future ‚Äî 'If it rains, I will stay home.'
Second Conditional: Unreal or hypothetical ‚Äî 'If I won the lottery, I would travel the world.'
Third Conditional: Past unreal ‚Äî 'If I had studied, I would have passed.'

content.text: Only the zero conditional talks about results that are *always* true when the condition is met.
The zero conditional appears in science, health, daily routines, and instructions.

items: Science: 'If you add salt to water, it boils at a higher temperature.'
Health: 'If you don‚Äôt sleep enough, you feel tired.'
Daily routine: 'If I drink coffee late, I can‚Äôt sleep.'
Instructions: 'If the machine stops, press the red button.'
